title: Unit 1: Limits and Continuity
subtitle: Understanding the Foundation of Calculus
description: Understand what limits really mean, visually.
objectives: Review essential Precalculus concepts and understand how Calculus builds upon them, including the tangent line and area problems.
Estimate limits using numerical, graphical, and analytical approaches, and identify cases where limits do not exist.
Evaluate limits using various techniques: limit laws, factoring, rationalizing, and the Squeeze Theorem.
Understand continuity at a point and across intervals using one-sided limits and continuity properties.
Apply the Intermediate Value Theorem and classify different types of discontinuities.
Analyze infinite limits, limits at infinity, and sketch vertical asymptotes of function graphs.
bigIdeas: Can change occur at an instant?
How does knowing the value of a limit, or that a limit does not exist, help you to make sense of interesting features of functions and their graphs?
How do we close loopholes so that a conclusion about a function is always true?
Calculus allows us to generalize knowledge about motion to diverse problems involving change.
Reasoning with definitions, theorems, and properties can be used to justify claims about limits.
